dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an old joke.  Uh, two elderly  women are at a Catskills mountain  resort, and one of 'em says: "Boy, the  food at this place is really terrible."  The other one says, "Yeah, I know, and  such ... small portions." Well, that's  essentially how I feel about life.  Full  of loneliness and misery and suffering  and unhappiness, and it's all over much  too quickly.  The-the other important  joke for me is one that's, uh, usually  attributed to Groucho Marx, but I think  it appears originally in Freud's wit and  its relation to the unconscious.  And it  goes like this-I'm paraphrasing: Uh ...  "I would never wanna belong to any club  that would have someone like me for a  member." That's the key joke of my adult  life in terms of my relationships with  women.  Tsch, you know, lately the  strangest things have been going  through my mind, 'cause I turned forty,  tsch, and I guess I'm going through a  life crisis or something, I don't know.  I, uh ... and I'm not worried about aging.   I'm not one o' those characters, you know.  Although I'm balding slightly on top, that's  about the worst you can say about me.  I,  uh, I think I'm gonna get better as I get  older, you know?  I think I'm gonna be the- the balding virile type, you know, as  opposed to say the, uh, distinguished  gray, for instance, you know?  'Less I'm  neither o' those two. Unless I'm one o'  those guys with saliva dribbling out of  his mouth who wanders into a cafeteria  with a shopping bag screaming about  socialism.  (Sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and I broke up and I-I still can't  get my mind around that.  You know, I-I  keep sifting the pieces of the relationship  through my mind and-and examining my life  and tryin' to figure out where did the  screw-up come, you know, and a year ago we  were... tsch, in love.  You know, and-and-and  ... And it's funny, I'm not-I'm not a  morose type.  I'm not a depressive character.   I-I-I, uh,  (Laughing)

dialogues.text: you know, I was a reasonably happy kid,  I guess.  I was brought up in Brooklyn  during World War II.

dialogues.text: (Puffing on his cigarette and  nodding)

dialogues.text: Something he read, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (His head still down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The universe is expanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The universe is expanding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking up at the doctor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the universe is everything, and if  it's expanding, someday it will break apart  and that would be the end of everything! Disgusted, his mother looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.text: What is that your business?  (she turns back to the doctor)

dialogues.text: He stopped doing his homework.

dialogues.text: What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Excited, gesturing with her hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has the universe got to do with it?   You're here in Brooklyn!  Brooklyn is not  expanding!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Heartily, looking down at Alvy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't be expanding for billions of years  yet, Alvy.  And we've gotta try to enjoy  ourselves while we're here.  Uh? He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -coaster in the Coney Island section of  Brooklyn.  Maybe that accounts for my  personality, which is a little nervous, I  think.

dialogues.text: I remember the staff at our public  school.  You know, we had a saying, uh,  that "Those who can't do, teach, and  those who can't teach, teach gym." And  ...uh, h'h, of course, those who couldn't  do anything, I think, were assigned to  our school.  I must say-

dialogues.text: A female teacher standing in front of an old-fashioned sc blackboard behind her reads "Transportation Administratio her point of view: a group of young students sitting behi as a child sits in a center desk wile all around him ther there is note-passing, ruler-tapping, nose-picking, gumch

dialogues.text: I always felt my schoolmates were idiots.   Melvyn Greenglass, you know, fat little  face, and Henrietta Farrell, just Miss  Perfect all the time.  And-and Ivan  Ackerman, always the wrong answer.  Always.  Ivan stands up behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In nineteen forty-two I had already dis- As Alvy talks, the camera shows him move from his seat an She jumps from her seat in disgust, rubbing her cheek, as his seat.

dialogues.text: Ugh, he kissed me, he kissed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (First off screen, then onscreen as  camera moves over to the back of the  classroom)

dialogues.text: Why, I was just expressing a healthy sexual  curiosity.

dialogues.text: (The younger, Alvy standing next to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: I lost track of most of my old schoolmates,  but I wound up a comedian.  They did not take  me in the Army.  I was, uh ... Interestingly  enough, I was-I was four-P. Sounds of TV audience laughter and applause are heard.

No, not  did you eat, but Jew eat?  Jew.  You get it?   Jew eat?

Listen to this -so I know there's  this big tall blond crew-cutted guy and  he's lookin' at me in a funny way and  smiling and he's saying, "Yes, we have a  sale this week on Wagner." Wagner, Max,  Wagner-so I know what he's really tryin'  to tell me very significantly Wagner.

Granted, La Strada was a great  film.  Great in its use of negative energy  more than anything else.  But that simple  cohesive core ... dialogues.text: Oh-
